Ernesto Zedillo ..DH: Tackling Economic Crises, Corruption and Political Violence in Mexico

No Mexican president in modern times has faced the array of problems--from economic crisis to armed insurrection--that Ernesto Zedillo has in his first 21 months in office. Yet, Zedillo does not appear overwhelmed. Indeed, he is no longer the accidental candidate who filled the political vacuum created by the assassination of Luis Donaldo Colosio, his party's presidential candidate, in March 1994. Zedillo confidently predicts that he will pull his country out of its state of emergency in the near future.

Unfortunately for him, such confidence is not widely shared in other quarters of Mexico--especially where there are strong doubts about Zedillo's abilities as a leader.

Until now, the Zedillo administration, with public support, has been able to pass most of the blame for the country's ills onto the previous administration of Carlos Salinas de Gortari. This has given Zedillo the freedom to make progress on some key fronts. He has adjusted the economy to a devalued peso and brought about the start of a recovery. He has successfully negotiated an agreement among Mexico's major political parties to achieve political reform. He has strengthened the muscle of the judiciary branch by reconstituting the supreme court and purging the ranks of the corrupted federal police. He has called in the military to cleanse Mexico City's police force. He claims to have captured the hired guns who killed Colosio and another prominent politician.

These accomplishments are undeniable, but Zedillo is still far from achieving success. Jobs lost during the severe economic recession have not been replaced. Businesses that went belly up after the peso was devalued in December 1994 have not reopened. His handling of the economy has drawn strong political opposition, even from within his own party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI). A persistent wave of criminal violence, fed, in large part, by drug trafficking, plagues Mexico's cities and towns.

Then there are Mexico's two continuing insurrections. In Chiapas, talks with Subcomandante Marcos and his Zapatistas have been suspended. In southern and central Mexico, an especially violent revolutionary group, known as the Popular Revolutionary Army (EPR), recently staged a series of daring attacks in six Mexican states, leaving 16 dead.

Sitting in his office at Los Pinos, Zedillo, trim and fit, discussed these enormous problems sounding more like a scientist than a politician--but never ducking an opportunity to take on his critics. Yet, for many Mexicans, the question is whether their president has the fire to exercise the kind of authority needed to govern Mexico.

*

Question: You have made a distinction between the EPR and the Zapatistas. And, in fact, you have a strange type of official relationship with the Chiapas group. The government allows an armed group of people who want to overthrow the government to organize tours for Hollywood movie-makers. What is going on?

Answer: Well, in Chiapas we are half-way solving the problem. We want to reach an agreement in which the government accepts the just social and political claims of this group and, in return, they disarm and join the political route to participate in the civic life of the country. In between, there is no violence, they keep their arms and are free to organize their propaganda activities.

Q: Violence, however, has made a comeback and many analysts believe the national-security apparatus in Mexico has collapsed since 1994.

A: Violence has many varieties and is surfacing. But this is happening not only in Mexico. There seems to be a new wave of violence worldwide--sometimes even promoted by the media. In Mexico, we have had political assassinations, and we don't know yet what were the causes for those murders, because they are extremely complicated cases. The investigation continues its course. Regarding violence perpetrated by common criminals, the explanation is that our laws have been too lenient and our institutions have failed because they have not grown as the country has grown. Some of these institutions have been corrupted. So we're adjusting our laws to the times we are living in and reforming our institutions.

Q: Regarding the assassination of Luis Donaldo Colosio, there is a genuine concern of a sector of society, but some people are also using it for political gain. Do you see it that way?

A: I have always condemned the sensationalization and the extra-legal pressures used in this case. Almost every week, there is a new hypothesis of the killing. Everybody has the right to express an opinion, but sensationalism and extra-legal pressures dilute the search for truth and the achievement of justice. Some people would like me to become prosecutor and judge; to do so would be illegal and useless. What I have done, as president, is to ensure the absolute independence of the judiciary system . . . .

Q: I know you don't believe there is a conspiracy in place since 1994, but do you believe there is a power struggle going on?

A: No. I honestly don't believe there is a power struggle going on. It would be easy for me to say that the problems I face are the byproducts of a conspiracy, but that would be a lie . . . . Each one of the troubles we've gone through has its own logic.

Q: In Mexico, the government is blamed for every problem, whether it is poverty or inequality or unemployment. What do you see as your responsibility?

A: My responsibility began Dec. 1, 1994, but the government has to confront each one of these problems. Poverty is a 500-year-old problem, but it is my problem now. Regarding our economic problems, I think they began three years ago. We went through a process of accumulation until the crisis burst . . . .

Q: The crisis began three years ago?

A: Yes. We had a very high deficit in the current-account {balance} in 1992, '93 and '94, and we allowed ourselves to reach a situation that led us to the crisis. But that is irrelevant. Now that is my problem and I must solve it.

Q: However, in April 1994, you told me, "After 10 years of macroeconomic adjustments, we can now tell the people they will reap the benefits after so much sacrifice." Either you did not know what was happening or there were mistakes later. Also troubling is the fact that you were the programming and budget secretary.

A: Yes, but up until 1991.

Q: But you were the candidate.

A: That is a good question and let's deal with it. To run into a crisis, you have to link a series of events that individually would hardly create a crisis. It is like an accident. We had a serious dependency on foreign capital. Some saw this flow of capital as a positive sign, as a symbol of economic vitality, of confidence in our country. However, when some events shook the confidence of the foreign investor, the flow was read in a different light. Remember, the money for these so-called emergent markets came from new and different sources, the stock exchange, pension funds, etc. Nobody knew how they would behave in an emergent market if a given situation would turn out different from the norm. These were the factors we had to confront . . . .

One reason why we are coming out of this national emergency is precisely because the Mexican economy has a structural strength it had never had. After the 1982 crisis, it took us seven years to begin to see the light at the end of the tunnel, because our economy back then was obsolete, unproductive and incapable of functioning in the current global economy.

Q: Do you believe there should have been a devaluation before the election?

A: In retrospect, it is real easy to say that, and it certainly could have been much more comfortable to start my government with an economy in the process of a severe adjustment.

Q: But would you have won the election after a devaluation?

A: The only time I am aware that a devaluation was considered was on Nov. 20, 1994. That was 10 days before my inauguration.

Q: What happened in December '94, and who is responsible?

A: I wish the crisis had been the result of one decision--because it would not have been as big a crisis and it would have been easy to solve. We had a crisis because the country was spending more than it was producing. This took years, and then there were so many more issues involved. We had become addicted to flows of foreign capital, and these represented 7% or 8% of GNP. We also had to pay more than $41 billion in bonds, shares, Tesobonos, Cetes that matured around that date. These problems were not created in one day. We had to adjust the country back to reality and that is precisely what made an impact in the people's living standards.

Q: Some critics say you have a long-term vision, to build up an efficient, competitive economy, whereas the people have short-term needs--they want a job or higher wages. Is this a problem?

A: My responsibility is to work long term, but that does not mean we don't measure the short-term effects of long-term actions. If we had followed an adjustment program in '95, in the short term it would have meant more sacrifices for the people and it would have taken longer to overcome the economic emergency. Gradualism is not an option, because that would have taken us to total collapse and instead of loosing hundreds of thousands of jobs, we would have lost millions. My long-term policy is the best policy in the short term. Promises won't bring food to the table of the people.

Q: What most dominates the relationship between Mexico and the United States: conflict or cooperation?

A: It is a complex relationship that has many facets and many issues, some extremely difficult. This complexity forces a chiaro/oscuro type of relationship. President Clinton is very cooperative and has helped us in the most difficult of times. It took a lot of guts to support Mexico as he did. Fortunately, we have paid them back almost the whole loan.

There's been respect when dealing with difficult issues--such as drug trafficking or immigration; but both countries have tried to solve problems as they come up. From time to time, we have problems like the Helms-Burton law, which I believe is a big mistake, because it violates international law. That is why it is creating so many problems with Canada, the European Union and us. But Helms-Burton cannot contaminate the whole relationship; I hope we can overcome this problem.

Q: President Clinton's special envoy for Cuba, Stuart Eizenstat, said, "It would be a mistake to bring Helms-Burton into NAFTA." Did you interpret it as a threat or as a warning?

A: Maybe he said so because he knows we are right, and the U.S. view is wrong. They are asking us to promote democracy in Cuba; well, they should know Mexico has maintained, consistently for many decades, the principle of non-intervention in the affairs of other nations. I believe democracy is the best political system, but I don't believe we have the right to interfere in Cuba's domestic affairs.

Q: Has the North American Free Trade Agreement worked well for the United States but not for Mexico?

A: NAFTA has performed very well for its three partners. Trade has increased in a meaningful way, and NAFTA passed a difficult test in '95. During the Mexican recession, it is remarkable that our purchases in the U.S. did not fall and are now growing strongly again. NAFTA is no longer a topic for debate, because we are not talking theory now, but facts.

Q: After the November election in the U.S., couldn't you find a similar framework that would lead to a treaty on immigration?

A: We have always been open to reach a permanent solution to this issue. The problem is that the existing economic disparity between both countries is what causes migration. The real solution will come with economic growth in Mexico, but that will take some time. Meanwhile, we should work out agreements to take care of the real demand for Mexican labor in the U.S. in an environment that respects human rights. This approach is difficult for the U.S., because it would mean legalizing many more immigrants than what is politically feasible.

Q: How would you describe yourself? Are you a weak president, as many people say?

A: How arrogant and vain would it be that I define myself. I am not pursuing an "image," because I cannot waste my time on those silly exercises. I have been through the hardest period ever for a president in modern Mexico, and when things are difficult, the people demand miraculous and messianic solutions. I have been responsible in avoiding promises no one can deliver. I have remained truthful through painful times. I try, deliberately, not to make authoritarian use of the presidential powers. One of the imperfections of our democracy has been its lack of equilibrium between the federal powers and among the three branches of government. My contribution has been to open spaces for other powers. Because nobody can accuse me of being a thief or corrupt or abusive, they say I am weak. That's fine. I answer my critics with deeds and tough decisions I have had to make without ever considering my index of popularity.

Global View: On Global Issues, Perot Sounds Texas League

At the G-7 economic summit in Munich this week George Bush and six other heads of government are tackling such knotty matters as how to help Russia avoid a dangerous economic collapse, how to break the Uruguay Round deadlock and how to regenerate world-wide economic growth.

Mr. Bush will be in an anomalous position. He is the most powerful national leader at Munich but is at the same time losing the support of voters at home. That would be more serious were it not for the fact that his fellow leaders, with the possible exception of John Major, are no better off. Whether that will make the seven chieftains more fraternal or more touchy in their deliberations is anyone's guess. Insecure politicians sometimes are better bedfellows than confident ones.

But since we are discussing Mr. Bush's political problems, let's imagine for a moment that the U.S. leader at Munich is not George Bush, but President Ross Perot. The diminutive Texan has been first choice in some recent popularity polls and is expected to announce his presidential candidacy soon. He can no longer be ignored, however unlikely it is that the well-justified anti-Beltway mood of the voters will translate into an actual Perot victory. Would Mr. Perot be any good at what is arguably the most important constitutional responsibility of an American President, the conduct of foreign policy?

What little evidence exists is not encouraging. Trade is the only foreign policy issue that Mr. Perot has addressed in any detail. His orientation was not that of a world leader but of a narrowly focused Texas businessman. Specifically, he attacked George Bush's efforts to bring the U.S., Canada and Mexico into a North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). He treated a press conference to a twangy dissertation on why a businessman, under conditions of free trade, would "naturally" move his factory from the U.S. to Mexico to take advantage of lower wage and pension costs and other presumed advantages. American workers would suffer, he said.

In fact, this seemingly pragmatic logic is not pragmatic at all, even on its own narrow terms. Factory owners do not move production willy-nilly. They consider sunk costs in existing facilities. Nor do they locate new plants solely on the basis of raw labor costs. They consider proximity to markets, transportation costs, the educational level of the work force, the political stability of the host country, the willingness of managers to relocate, the availability of parts and raw materials and a good many other factors.

Removal of tariff barriers in the European Community has not caused German manufacturers to move en masse to Greece or Portugal, even though labor costs certainly are lower there. What has in fact happened is that both the northern and southern countries of the EC have developed, as is invariably the case when restrictions on commerce are removed. Markets for both goods and labor become broader, allowing companies to take advantage of economies of scale and comparative advantage. It is a dynamic process, involving temporary job losses certainly but, on balance, upward mobility for able workers to better, more productive jobs.

Most Americans know all this intuitively. They have seen the world open up with new opportunities. Japanese auto companies create jobs in Ohio, Kentucky and Tennessee. Bavarische Motoren Werke AG of Germany has just announced a plan to build a $625 million assembly plant near Spartanburg, S.C., drawing parts and components from Germany, Austria, the U.S. and, yes, Mexico. As they see all this internationalization of business taking place around them, Americans consistently reject protectionist reaction.

Yet here is Mr. Perot, in his first ventures into saying something that sounds like a policy position, using those old protectionist code words, "level playing field" and "fair trade." Anyone who has spent many hours, as I have, listening to businessmen lobby for trade barriers has heard it all many times.

On the basis of what we know so far, a President Perot at Munich would be punching air with parochial slogans instead of furthering the interests of the U.S. and the world in a freer global business environment. John Major, who is trying to rid the United Kingdom of the vestiges of corporatism, would be appalled to hear a Ross Perot talking about assembling American CEO's to find ways to make the U.S. more competitive. He might suggest, if Mr. Perot cared to listen, that CEOs are better employed running their own companies than trying to collaborate with politicians on national industrial policy schemes.

Then there is the question of personality. An American President does not need to be a silky voiced diplomat, but he must take other national leaders seriously. Mr. Perot has seemed singularly incapable of taking anyone seriously other than himself. He described his fellow board members at General Motors as "pet rocks." That made a hit with GM's critics but also signalled to Roger Smith that Mr. Perot's ego was far too large to allow him to be of much use in achieving the goal the two of them shared, a streamlining of the GM bureaucracy.

Which poses the central problem of Ross Perot. The qualities that are winning him a political following are also the ones that cast doubts on his chances for a successful presidency. His fiesty, iconoclastic style raises hopes that he might be able to reassert presidential control over the U.S. government and wrench it out of the hands of Congress and the special interests Congress serves. But he has not said or done anything so far that suggests he is capable of such a feat. He is clearly bright but his few policy utterances, such as that dealing with NAFTA, suggest ignorance on major national and international issues. His one-man-band approach to problem solving ignores the fact that today the most important thing an American President can do is strengthen alliances against all the forces for political fragmentation that now are loose in the world. There are few of those alliances more important than the one with Japan, the bete noire of American protectionists. East Asia's potential for political instability is high and the U.S. has a large stake in that region, in the form of both trade and investment.

At Munich, a President Perot would find himself face to face with men much more experienced in politics than he. None of them are "pet rocks," he would soon find out. But they all would know, perhaps better than he, that the U.S. is not a competitive basket case but rather a very powerful country, both politically and economically. Should he not be able to supply the leadership they want, they would quickly search for alternatives. The world would get messier, and down-home homilies would be of no help.

A better U.S. target in Japan--the consumer

With the summit behind him, Kiichi Miyazawa has given Bill Clinton his best going-away present. He's told the president that Japan cannot accept Mickey Kantor's insistence on targets, but he has agreed to the growth of U.S. exports in Japan's market. Not a bad deal for the president, since export targets not only tend to become export ceilings, but would also have strengthened Japan's bureaucracy.

The president can now move on to a new agenda, but he and his people are going to have to adopt a two-part strategy. First, they need to put away the bludgeon; all that does is confirm the deep fear of the Japanese that they are being victimized. Second, the U.S. will have to show that when we talk about a "partnership" we mean it. But that's going to require that the president's people do their homework on the real state of play in U.S.-Japanese trade.

Listening to the common wisdom that most of our top exports to Japan are raw materials -- such as maize, raw wood and fish -- won't do it. The reality is the opposite -- and has been for years. Easily 60% of our exports to Japan are manufactured goods, and most of them are of the hightech variety. The adjacent table shows the value of our top five exports through 1991, and in 1992 the top four categories were: $3.9 billion for transportation; $3.6 billion for office and automatic data processing equipment and parts; $2.6 billion for electrical machinery, and $2.4 billion for cork and wood.

Neither will listening to those who insist on talking down the dollar. That policy has been tried since 1985. The result is that while the volume of Japan's oil imports rose by 26% compared with 1985, its bill last year for oil and related products was just 39% of its 1985 cost.

The reason: Oil is denominated in dollars. That means we've given Japan a huge discount on its commodity imports, and at the same time nearly doubled the cost to U.S. firms of doing business in Japan. And the high cost of setting up in Japan, rather than tariffs or closed markets, was listed by Americans there as the chief deterrent to greater U.S. investment and exports.

The president has got it right in targeting the Japanese consumer. For the best part of a year, Japan's press has been carrying stories about the rigged bids in the construction business, Liberal Democratic Party ties to gangsters, and what brought it all out -- the gold bars in Shin Kanemaru's house. All this confirmed what ordinary folks had long suspected: They are being ripped off; the prices they pay are crazily high, compared with just about anywhere else. More and more Japanese see this firsthand, since 10 million to 15 million of them travel overseas each year, a third to the U.S. alone.

We had a good illustration when one of my wife's Japanese friends came to visit. The first place she wanted to see was the local Safeway: to confirm that a 20-pound bag of rice sells here for about $6 to $7, and not the $45 to $50 it brings in Japan. Sure, Japan's bubble has burst, but the U.S. has held its share of the Japanese market. Over the past two years, Japan's imports from the European Community dropped 10%, but from the U.S. hardly at all: Imports in 1990 were $52.4 billion; in 1992, $52.2 billion.

Finally, while the Japanese don't particularly welcome the North American Free Trade Agreement, they understand the pressures behind it. But how can the U.S. seriously consider extending NAFTA to Chile, and now to Argentina, when there are more attractive prospects in Asia? Singapore alone -- with just 2.8 million people -- buys more from the U.S. than those two, and South Korea and Taiwan add an additional $15 billion each.

But every time the U.S. mentions Chile and Argentina as the next candidates for NAFTA -- or worse yet inludes Singapore -- Japan begins to think about its trading partners in Asia. Unless Washington wants to promote a world of regional blocs, it needs to consider Korea, Taiwan and, yes, Japan in that format. Now that's a real eye-popper, designed to respond to Japan's new-found emphasis on reform and Bill Clinton's talk of a new agenda.

The outlook: Trade policy stumbles on rich vs. poor states

WASHINGTON -- Rich countries with poor neighbors are suffering a bout of economic anxiety.

Fearful that Mexico might sap the U.S. job market, Congress may throttle the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would phase in barrier-free trade between the U.S. and its neighbors to the south and north. Similarly, the European Community has been slow to open its markets to the struggling economies of the former East bloc. In Asia, Japan invests heavily in the nearby "tiger" economies, but shields domestic producers from the low-cost goods that the tigers export.

Working out economic arrangements with less-developed countries "is the forefront question of trade policy," says Gary Hufbauer, economist with the Institute for International Economics. "The difficulties," says economist Herbert Stein, "stem from a common error and prejudice that you lose jobs if you have to compete with anybody."

One problem is that the less developed states are edging into the world economy in the worst of times. The U.S. is experiencing a tepid recovery, with major industries still shrinking and restructuring. Western Europe is sunk in a general recession, with unemployment pushing toward 12%. Japan's been hit by the worst slump in years, its financial bubble largely deflated.

Vladimir Dlouhy, the Czech Republic's minister of industry and trade, complains that the EC's 1993 quota for steel imports is lower even than the previous year's level. But, citing economic conditions, he adds, "I don't expect much improvement."

In the current environment, many see their less-developed neighbors not so much as a new market to sell to, but a threat to a shaky job base at home. "We don't give a fig about the Mexican market," says Jock Nash, Washington counsel for Milliken & Co., a privately owned textile concern that probably would suffer if NAFTA goes through. He argues that companies would shift production to Mexico, where wages are about one-tenth of U.S. levels, then sell their products back into the U.S. market. "If American manufacturers move offshore to stay competitive in our own markets, we're through," he warns.

Japan, whose approach to less-developed neighbors appeals to some Westerners, invests in the fast-growing East Asian economies like Thailand and Indonesia without allowing the resulting output to threaten domestic producers. Japanese plants in Thailand, for example, don't sell back to Japan, but to the U.S.

Critics, however, are using imports and immigrants as scapegoats for broader problems afflicting low-skilled workers. Some economists argue that U.S. industrial workers are far more threatened by robots at home than peasants abroad. "I don't think what happened to unskilled labor in the 1980s can be attributed to international trade with undeveloped countries," says Jagdish Bhagwati, economist at Columbia University. "A great deal of work shows that 95% of the stagnation in wages in the 1980s is attributable to technology."

As technological advances increase productivity and lessen the demand for labor, wage levels for unskilled U.S. workers languish. But outside certain labor-intensive sectors where developing countries have an advantage, the U.S. has attracted foreign investors, some of whom choose the U.S. as a base for the larger NAFTA market. Mr. Bhagwati's studies show that during the 1980s, more jobs were created by foreign investors in the U.S. than by U.S. companies moving plants to low-wage countries like Mexico.

One reason is that productivity in the hinterlands of many countries still lags. According to a senior U.S. trade official, if Mexico grew as fast as Japan did in the 1960s, it would take 30 years to reach the productivity levels of Italy, which are well below those in the U.S. Similarly, East European productivity is years behind that of its Western neighbors.

Those fighting trade-opening moves "just look at the narrow, first-order job losses," says Stephen Roach, a Morgan Stanley & Co. economist. "What they don't point out is that as income levels rise, our developing neighbors look beyond their borders for high-value products."

Indeed, the running U.S. trade surplus with Mexico, which came to $5.4 billion last year, indicates that so far, Mexico's economic development is mainly creating demand for U.S. goods. Moreover, U.S. wages in export-related jobs run 17% higher than the average manufacturing wage, suggesting that international trade is supporting higher-value jobs at home.

However, both in the U.S. and Europe, the critics of more open trade are drowning out the companies and workers that stand to gain. "In Europe, the gainers from open trade are a lot of people who make small gains, and the losers, like agriculture and steel, make big losses," says Jim Rollo, economist with the Royal Institute for International Affairs in London.

The fear-mongers circling NAFTA -- and their counterparts overseas -- should focus on the real problem: namely, workers with low skills in a world economy that demands higher skills and ever-improving productivity. If the U.S. dumps NAFTA and closes its borders to foreign goods tomorrow, that segment of the work force still faces a dismal future. At least with expanding trade, says Mr. Stein, "there should be some way to use the net gains to assist those who are injured."

Letting Mexico Grow

"The government believes at the moment that a fiscal surplus is more important than growth. But Mexico is mainly attractive as an investment because of its growth potential."

-- Eduardo Medina-Mora, subdirector of strategic planning at the industrial holding company, Desc.

"The cost of capital is killing us. The big guys can borrow outside the country or place bonds through Goldman Sachs. But many midsize and small companies have to borrow at home. And we can't get the prime rate of 19%. We must pay between 25% and 30%."

-- Eduardo Garza, president of a midsize steel production firm in Monterrey.

"If I operated legally, maybe I could get loans and grow. But I'd go broke if I had to deal with all the regulations and taxes I'd have to pay."

-- Ebba, an underground entrepreneur who sells poultry out of her home in a Mexico City suburb.

Mexico's growth juggernaut is slowing down. From the industrial giants like Alfa and Vitro, to the midsize companies, right on down to the informal vendors, the costs of doing business in Mexico are increasing while projected earnings are falling. Official growth projections have been downgraded to under 3% for this year compared with projections of 4% made a year ago, and some worry that growth may be dead in the water.

Up until now, there has been little question about the current administration's commitment to strong growth. Since becoming president in 1988, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and his economic team have embraced a plethora of supplyside growth initiatives, often in defiance of international "experts." These initiatives included dramatic tax rate cuts, an opening to foreign goods and capital, deregulation of capital markets, massive privatizations and an opening for private investments in economic areas heretofor reserved for the state.

The Mexican market responded to these actions like desert flowers in a rainstorm. Private-sector investment bloomed. Capital markets and inflows from abroad surged. Formerly protected businesses learned to compete and found the resources to do so by joining the world financial system. Government revenue from tax receipts doubled, leading to the first budget surplus in Mexican history; and, in an atmosphere of strict monetary discipline, inflation did what all the Phillips-curve-critics of President Salinas's bullish growth strategy said was impossible: It decreased to a projected annual rate of 11% this year from 159% in 1987.

But several months ago, the economy turned wobbly. While officials were boasting in world forums about their budget surplus, Mexican firms were reeling at the enormous cost of capital at home. Lower growth projections increased the possibility that the peso was overvalued. Even the booming stock market became fickle, fluctuating wildly at the slightest indication of bad news at home or abroad.

Of course, Mexico's growth slowdown began in the context of a world recession. But not all of Mexico's slowdown can be attributed to outside factors. The administration, while perhaps not actively suppressing growth, has momentarily made anti-inflationary goals paramount.

President Salinas doesn't put it exactly that way. "We do not believe that you have to sacrifice growth in order to have lower inflation," said the president in an interview last month. "But we are facing today a situation in which you can not sustain high growth due to the international situation. And since we are going through that transition we are taking advantage of that situation precisely to collapse inflation."

The problem is that many firms in Mexico, as well as foreign investors, see Mexico's need to grow as a more immediate concern. "The number one concern of Mexican businesses is to remain competitive," says Alejandro Guzman, president of Monterrey's Coparmex, an industrial chamber. "And that's not easy to do with the high cost of capital in Mexico now."

Not all analysts agree on the cause of Mexico's high cost of capital. Some bankers blame stringent requirements placed on their activities in March by the central bank. Most others blame Finance Minister Pedro Aspe's insistence on running an annual budgetary surplus, currently running at 0.4% of the country's gross national product.

One would expect such restraint more from the Bundesbank than from a Latin government. But what's right for developed Germany may not be right for a developing country like Mexico. Mexico needs to build infrastructure. And as long as the government maintains its commitment to strong growth and a strong currency -- a commitment that could be much enhanced by anchoring the peso to the dollar -- growth bonds could be issued to sustain the needed socioeconomic overhaul. But to do this, Mexico would likely have to give up its precious surplus.

Economists David Goldman and Evan Kalimtgis from the New Jersey firm Polyconomics remarked on this in a report they published in September: "Mexico's position resembles that of a young family which must mortgage future earnings potential in order to purchase a home. . . . A young economy, like a young individual, does not have a sufficient wealth buffer to sustain a drop in earnings."

Mr. Aspe appreciates the sentiment, but rejects the advice: "If you were to ask me, `Pedro, structurally, for a country like Mexico, what would be the right policy?' I'd answer straight: a fixed exchange rate with a small fiscal deficit of between 0% and 2%. But we have not reached that level because: first, inflation is still very high; and second, because NAFTA hasn't been passed. When these two things are locked up, then we can follow a more aggressive growth strategy."

One can well understand the Mexican government's concern about inflation and the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But are these goals really jeopardized by a more adventuresome commitment to stronger growth? In fact, the greatest threat to NAFTA may well be slow growth. If exporters to Mexico, or potential joint venture partners, or even those speculative investors who view all of Mexico as a growth stock, perceive that Mexico is not doggedly committed to growth, their interest in the treaty will diminish.

As for inflationary pressures in the economy, it's difficult to spot many rising consumer prices. Nevertheless, from the high cost of capital, land and managerial labor to the tremendously complex tax and regulatory codes, production costs in Mexico are as high as ever. "If you take a Mexican company in the manufacturing industry with the same cost structure as a U.S. company, the tax burden for the Mexican company is substantially higher," says Desc's Mr. Medina-Mora. And since Mexican trading doors were opened, Mexican producers can't pass their costs on to a captive consumer; that consumer can now buy foreign. This cuts entrepreneurs' enthusiasm about NAFTA.

Mexican firms are not looking for an artificial boost through an arbitrary lowering of interest rates or a devaluation of the currency. "Most of us generally support the macro policies of the government," says Monterrey steel company owner Eduardo Garza. "But it still takes months to start up a business in Mexico today. Many entrepreneurs simply give up in frustration or operate in the underground economy. The government must push harder to deregulate the economy and get rid of all the disincentives."

In this area, help may be on its way. Trade minister Jaime Serra recently announced a 12-point program of fiscal and regulatory incentives to boost the supply side of the Mexican economy. These changes compliment others that have been on line for several months, including: elimination of capital gains taxes for the transfer of properties; the ability to fully deduct in the first year all the present discounted value of an investment (excluding Mexico City, Guadalajara and Monterrey); an overhaul of Mexico's antiquated port facilities; and hints that Mexico's strangulating labor laws (which hamper the flexibiilty of both workers and managers) may be overhauled as well.

Despite the slowdown, Mexico still seems like a coiled spring ready to pop at 5% to 10% growth a year. President Salinas admits that "we are capable of sustaining rates of 6% in real terms per year." But the longer the government keeps the spring coiled, the greater the chance that it loses its elasticity. The Mexican government has to take larger steps to prove to the U.S. and to its own people that it is seriously committed to releasing the juggernaut. If not, precisely those indicators that Mr. Aspe is waiting for -- passage of NAFTA and an inflation rate competitive with the U.S. -- may slip from its grasp. --- Mr. Asman edits the Americas column.

Potomac watch: Gore shakes, Newt rattles, GATT unrolls

Armed with his Adam Smith necktie, Joe Cobb has tilted at the World Bank and other global bureaucracies for years. Yet last week the Republican economist found himself defending President Clinton's global trade pact against attacks from a fellow right-thinker, Newt Gingrich.

Their unlikely behind-the-scenes scrape portends another political problem for a Clinton White House that never takes the easy route when an ordeal is available. Only a few weeks ago the landmark General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) looked like a gimme putt in Congress. But a lack of White House attention has let the tariff-cutting pact drift into jeopardy for this year, and maybe forever if Mr. Clinton doesn't spend some political capital.

"I'm very concerned," says GOP Rep. David Dreier, a California free-trader who helped Mr. Clinton win his NAFTA battle. "I'm hoping to see more effort."

It shouldn't be this hard. Ross Perot is sitting out this fight, at least so far, while unions are applying most of their muscle to labor law and health care. Those intellectual comrades, Ralph Nader and Pat Buchanan, are lobbing sound bites but sway few votes. Even Dick Gephardt, the Democrats' ranking trade warrior, has suggested he'll support GATT.

Maybe that's why Mr. Gingrich's rebellion caught the White House napping. On NAFTA he was Mr. Clinton's savior, delivering 132 GOP votes (to just 102 Democrats). But Sunday on NBC's "Meet the Press," the de facto House Republican leader raised the specter of lost U.S. sovereignty under GATT. He fretted about the pact's provision for a new World Trade Organization (WTO), in which the U.S. "could be outvoted by Antigua, by Botswana or by Venezuela," among other nemeses.

"I'm for world trade," said the Georgia bulldog, "but I'm against world government."

What Mr. Gingrich didn't say was that five days earlier he'd heard a similar spiel from Roger Milliken, the legendary textile protectionist, and Pat Choate, Mr. Perot's trade guru. On NAFTA, Mr. Gingrich had broken with Mr. Milliken, who has been a financial supporter of the Georgian's political causes. Has the House's leading Republican gone for a swim in the fever swamps?

Mr. Cobb, the GOP economist who's studied the GATT text, says yes, because the WTO is no threat to American self-rule. "It's quite silly," he says. "The WTO has no executive authority; it's a mechanism for settling trade disputes. The argument is a red herring." Mr. Cobb works for that famous one-world conspiracy front, the Heritage Foundation. He says he'd shutter both the World Bank and International Monetary Fund if he could, but the WTO is different.

The WTO does have stronger enforcement powers than in the past. But that's exactly what the U.S. sought during seven years of trade talks, so that protectionists would have to abide by sterner global rules. Mr. Gingrich rightly says that power will always trump rules, but the U.S. remains the biggest trading power in the world. Are Botswana and Antigua, to pick just two mortal threats, going to endanger the U.S. with trade reprisals? In any case, say advocates, any substantive change in WTO rules couldn't apply to the U.S. unless Congress agreed.

Where Mr. Gingrich has a better point is in mistrusting White House instincts on such matters. At the GATT signing two weeks ago in Morocco, Vice President Gore sounded his one-world weirdest. The Americans shot down in Iraq "died in the service of the United Nations," he said by way of offering patriotic condolences.

That remark raised hackles in a GOP cloakroom already alarmed by the subordination of U.S. policy to the U.N. in Bosnia. Mr. Gore also waxed lyrical about how the WTO will spur "global dialogue," or worse, on world labor and environmental controls.

In reality, most of the world is more afraid of this Gore agenda than is even Mr. Gingrich, so none of it is going to happen. But someone might tell the veep that his rhetoric only gives red meat to Republicans who want an excuse to oppose GATT. The Clinton administration seems to be making the same mistake it did on NAFTA, which is to court votes on the left that it probably can't get anyway, while ignoring votes on the right that it needs to prevail.

The Clinton White House seems unable to sustain a centrist, bipartisan coalition even when it's in its own interests. Instead it always builds from the left first. Many House Republicans remember that Mr. Clinton didn't even single them out for thanks after their votes last time. So perhaps Mr. Gingrich is just issuing a warning to the president not to take GOP votes for granted this time.

But that's no reason to go further and scuttle a trade pact that amounts to one of the largest tariff cuts in world history. A tariff cut is really a tax cut, which is what Republicans are supposed to favor. Mr. Gingrich might even use his leverage to insist that these tariff/tax cuts will so boost trade that they'll produce more, not less, tariff revenue for the government (and thus require no offsetting tax hikes). Maybe Mr. Clinton will agree and christen it the Gingrich Curve -- a good precedent for the next tax debate.

The Americas: Flexible exchange rates will best serve Nafta

No one could argue that the three currencies of North America, two dollars and one peso, make a neat arrangement. Canada's dollar floats. The Mexican peso was propelled by the late 1994 currency crisis from a rate pegged to the U.S. dollar into a float even less predictable than that of Canada. The U.S. dollar? Well, it floats too in North America, since the other two currencies float around it.

This situation strikes quite a few commentators as unsatisfactory, whether seen from a strictly national point of view or more broadly as a currency arrangement for the North American Free Trade Agreement. They would like more fixity as a means of fostering trade and reducing financial uncertainty. But as currency set-ups go, the existing one is realistic in relation to underlying circumstances. With sound domestic financial policies, it is very satisfactory because it helps national economic adjustment.

The argument for fixing rates in aid of NAFTA requires critical examination. NAFTA is only what its name says it is -- a free trade agreement. It isn't even as much as a customs union, where the partners have unified tariffs for items originating outside the zone. NAFTA partners are free to negotiate separate tariffs with other nations. In particular, the U.S. clearly will continue to tackle some trade (and other) issues on its own.

Still less is NAFTA a common market, where the free flow of labor as well as capital across national borders is permitted, and where competition codes are harmonized by supranational legislation -- the Single European Act, for example. This is the context in which countries in Europe now envisage monetary union in 1999 via the Maastricht Treaty.

Whether Europe needs a single currency and therefore a single central bank, with all that this implies, to go with its developing common market continues to be debated by economists. It remains subject to political debate as well, especially in the U.K. However, the point here is that this debate takes place against a scenario of far more economic and political integration than has been dreamed of in North America. Indeed, to point up the contrast, part of the U.S. rationale for NAFTA was to provide Mexico with economic opportunities that would curb the migration of labor to the U.S. from Mexico. A common market would imply the reverse, a free flow of labor.

The difference between NAFTA and the EU supports the economic case for exchange rate flexibility in North America. Economic disturbances specific to Mexico or Canada do occur quite often. Exchange rate flexibility is helpful in coping with them. And the case for such flexibility is strengthened when workers themselves cannot adjust by moving freely across North American borders. Furthermore, there are no cross-border budgetary transfers to cushion such disturbances.

In any event, what could a monetary union mean in North America? In Europe it means pooling sovereignty among countries of reasonably equal size that would have balanced voting in the proposed common central bank. This is a nonstarter in North America. Canada and Mexico no doubt could use the U.S. dollar as legal tender if they wished. But this would not really be monetary union. Rather it would be official dollarization, with "official" only applying to one side.

The other side, the U.S., would surely look kindly on the use of its currency by close trading partners. It might even return to its NAFTA partners some of the seigniorage proceeds it would obtain through such use. What it could not be expected to do, however, is adapt its monetary policies to circumstances for the continent as a whole, as opposed to those for the U.S., or undertake to support banks outside its jurisdiction, even if those banks were funding themselves in U.S. dollars.

So clearly monetary union North American-style has institutional drawbacks. Even to try it, Mexico and Canada would need to have available the U.S. dollars to distribute in place of their own currencies. Canada could just about do that with the reserves it has, but Mexico is short. And to provide a backstop for the national banking system, each country would need either to hold additional U.S. dollars as a liquidity reserve fund or to have a reliable source from which to borrow them at short notice.

Fixing the exchange rate through a currency board scheme raises similar issues of financing. Argentina showed this in 1995 when it had to use IMF and World Bank funds to stave off a bank run. A more important consideration is that a currency board is a less intense commitment, because the government, rather than the general public, keeps hold of the U.S. dollars that support it. It is therefore less credible in principle than a monetary union. A pegged, or fixed-but-adjustable, rate is far less credible still, as Mexico's recent experience demonstrated.

Credibility is crucial. From this angle Canada could more readily establish a convincing fixed-rate arrangement than could Mexico, because its financial performance and economic structure are closer to U.S. patterns. But by the same token, for Canada the supposed credibility benefits of fixing would be less. Canadian inflation has been running below the U.S. pace for several years and Canadian interest rates, at least at the shorter end, are already lower than those in the U.S.

The U.S. might believe that fixity would avoid competitive currency depreciations by close trading partners. But in any case, a policy of competitive depreciation is not sustainable, and would not be in the national economic interest of Mexico or Canada either. In particular, such a misguided policy leads to inflation and high interest rates.

But to make clear that the exchange rate is not an instrument of trade policy is far from saying that it doesn't matter -- for trade or for the economy as a whole. And it is of course legitimate for monetary policy in both Canada and Mexico to concern itself with the exchange rate as well as with interest rates. For Canada the present low currency value reflects easier monetary conditions in a context of modest inflation and slow demand. For Mexico matters are more complicated, given the recent blow to confidence, the resulting high interest rates, and high residual inflation. But no one can doubt that demand overall in Mexico is weak, reducing inflationary pressure.

Canada has worked hard to establish a sound currency domestically, in its own economic interest. This effort also provides a solid foundation for a flexible Canadian dollar. The Bank of Mexico -- Mexico's central bank -- has further to go, but it is aiming in the same direction. As it moves further along that path, a floating peso will work better than it does now, because it will be operating against a background of domestic financial confidence.

The last straw

It's easy to sympathize with the oft-heard complaint of Latin Americans that the U.S. is interested in free trade only so long as it is Americans who benefit. Just consider Washington's latest trade dispute with Mexico.

Earlier this month, the Administration increased to 33% from 22% the tariff on imports of ordinary straw brooms from Mexico, citing the Emergency Action Chapter of NAFTA. This decision is yet another indication -- add it to U.S. protectionism against Mexican tomatoes, avocados and trucking -- that the spirit of NAFTA is perennially at risk due to the power of special interest groups. In this case, the U.S. Cornbroom Task Force, an industry group, argued that the tiny Mexican corn broom industry was injuring the even tinier U.S. corn broom industry -- even though broomcorn, a kind of sorghum, apparently isn't profitable enough to be grown in this country anymore. American broom makers import it from -- guess where? -- Mexico.

Mexico exports only about $7 million in corn brooms to the U.S. each year, which made it tough for the large broom industry here to argue that it had suffered an injury. In order to get around this inconvenient fact, the U.S. broom industry, which makes both plastic and corn brooms, argued that corn brooms are a separate industry from plastic brooms. Since U.S. broom makers have moved heavily toward plastic in recent years, a snapshot of the corn broom segment of the market produces the image of a Mexican corn broom industry of 2,500 workers swallowing up a small, shrinking industry of 600 American workers.

The cause of the American corn broom makers is helped by language in NAFTA specifying that tariffs can be restored if American broom makers suffer. This was engineered by Democratic Rep. Glenn Poshard of Illinois, home of Arcola, the self-styled "Broomcorn Capital of the World," where no broomcorn has grown for 20 years.

The Mexican corn broom industry is centered mostly in a poor region of the state of Nuevo Leon not far from the U.S. border. While the U.S. frets about Mexican job-seekers sneaking into California and Texas, lends billions of dollars in emergency funding to Mexico, and supports a variety of aid agencies whose objective is to end poverty there, it is ironic that it also suffocates competitive local businesses that wish to sell their wares in the U.S. With this ruling, Mexican producers will have less opportunity and U.S. consumers will pay more for brooms.

The North American Free Trade Agreement, once a proud peacock representing the future of freer trade on this continent, is slowly having its plumes plucked. The concept of comparative advantage -- the heart and soul of free trade theory -- appears to be completely lost on the managed traders in Washington. Every time it looks like a Mexican industry might have an edge over its U.S. counterpart, Washington cries foul and finds a way to up the tariff and save an antiquated industry.

The broom tariff was the last straw for Mexico. After battling for many months against U.S. trade policies that boosted the price of Mexican tomatoes, blocked the export of avocados and kept Mexican trucks from crossing the border, Mexico sent a message to Washington earlier this month that it had had enough. It boosted tariffs on eight U.S. products, including notebooks, wine coolers, brandy and Tennessee whiskey.

Economically speaking, retaliation doesn't make sense -- Mexicans don't win if children have to pay a premium for notebooks or grownups shell out more for a cocktail. Yet it's an indication of just how frustrated our southern neighbor is. Instead of bullying our NAFTA partner, the U.S. should lead the way in free trade, thereby helping U.S. consumers, Mexican workers and, yes, American workers as well. It's true that some corn broom makers may be forced to seek other work, but in the long run it is to the advantage of the U.S. to produce things for which it has a comparative advantage. Wrapping wire around straw is not where the future of the American economy lies.

NAFTA offers Latins little they can't have now

Once again the U.S. is flirting with its Latin American trading partners. Last week President Clinton began efforts to win fast-track negotiating authority in Congress, no doubt raising hopes that expansion of the North American Free Trade Agreement is in the wings. The trouble is that the administration's trade policy toward Latin America is highly political and actually harms the cause of freer trade in the region.

Consider the effects of the 1994 Miami Summit. By insinuating, suggesting and some would even say, promising that the U.S. would lead efforts to build a Free Trade Area of the Americas, the administration created an almost complete paralysis among Latin American trade policy makers. All around the region, plans to reduce import restrictions further have been shelved and programs to eliminate nontariff barriers postponed as the Latin American countries wait to see if (and when) they would be invited to join the great "regional integration" ball.

Worse yet, in many countries two misguided notions have taken hold. First, that maintaining protection at home would enhance these countries' negotiating position with the U.S., and second, that by forming regional trade blocs -- irrespective of the trade diversion they may generate -- the grand goal of achieving hemispheric integration would, in the end, be advanced.

Even pragmatic Chilean policy makers fell into the trap, and became obsessed with joining the NAFTA. This in spite of the fact that analysts have been unable to show persuasively that, when compared with other options, joining NAFTA would most benefit the country. And while they waited, they did nothing to further open their economy to the rest of the world.

After a series of snubs by the Clinton administration and Congress, however, Chile has recently decided to retake the road that had served the country so well in the past: unilaterally reducing its tariffs. This is a welcome announcement. By further integrating itself into the rest of the world -- import tariffs are supposed to be reduced to 7% in 1997 -- Chile will encourage productivity enhancements and will allow local producers greater access to world technology and capital goods.

Still, backtracking on trade liberalization in the rest of Latin America continues and is best demonstrated by Brazil's recent decision to severely limit import financing. Brazil's partners in the Mercosur customs union -- Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay -- have bitterly complained that this unilateral turn toward protectionism violates the spirit, as well as the letter, of that regional accord. This is a move toward greater protectionism and demonstrates a gross misunderstanding of the benefits and possibilities available to Brazil -- if it would only continue to open its economy to the world.

In spite of tremendous progress in trade liberalization during the first half of the 1990s, politicians in a number of countries in the region have begun to question the merits of additional opening. In many countries import restrictions have been raised in response to an array of pressures by special interest groups. The recent hike in import tariffs in Colombia, the increase in protectionism in Venezuela and Ecuador, and the use of administrative measures to control imports in Argentina and Mexico are all signs of this trend. Ironically these moves are taking place at a time when the Latin American countries should move aggressively, rapidly and unilaterally toward greater openness.

Many observers of Latin America believe that the region is already very open to the rest of the world. This is simply not true. In most Latin American nations import tariffs border on 15%. Although this is historically low for the region, it is still very high from an global perspective -- the average U.S. import tariff, for example, is approximately 3%. And most Latin American countries still have significant nontariff barriers. Latin America's relatively high levels of import protectionism have been recognized by some analysts, including Bryan T. Johnson and Thomas P. Sheehy of the Heritage Foundation. In their "The Index of Economic Freedom" (co-published by this newspaper), not a single Latin American nation is classified as having a "very low level" of protectionism, and only a handful are rated as having a "low level" of protectionism.

What's more alarming is that the progress that has been made in bringing down some trade barriers in Latin America -- and indeed the trend toward greater trade liberalization -- is now at risk.

Aside from special-interest politics, two factors have caused this shift in sentiment. First, there is still an important disagreement on whether "trade liberalization" packages have played an important role in the performance of the "miracle" economies of East Asia. Some academics, for example, have questioned the premise that trade liberalization is a necessary component of successful outward-oriented strategies, and have argued that the Asian Tigers' success has to a large extent depended on an active government role in promoting exports. Existing empirical evidence on the relationship between openness and growth is weak and unpersuasive, these observers allege. Second, in the last few years concern has grown that developing countries' trade liberalization may worsen income inequality and social conditions -- particularly hurting unskilled workers. These concerns, however, are largely unfounded.

Recent empirical research based on extensive new comparative data strongly suggests that countries whose economies become more integrated to the rest of the world experience an important boost in productivity growth. Moreover, mounting international evidence suggests that if labor markets are flexible and undistorted -- a requirement not met at this point by most Latin American countries -- major trade liberalization reforms will not generate transitional increases in unemployment, as many have feared.

Finally, a recent study by the Inter-American Development Bank has found that the lack of progress in many Latin American countries on income distribution and other social conditions cannot be attributed to their reform programs, including trade liberalization. This confirms previous OECD research suggesting that protectionism may actually increase income inequality in developing nations and that further integration into the world economy will improve social conditions in these countries.

Other countries in the region would do well to follow Chile's lead. By unilaterally opening to the rest of the world, instead of restricting themselves to a small clique of neighbors, the countries of Latin America will be able to take full advantage of the opportunities offered by the global economy.

Business World: Tree Growin' Man

Chuck Leavell considers it "pitiful" that only 0.06% of farm spending is devoted to subsidizing private forestry.

One responsibility of a columnist is to listen to rock'n'rollers who want to share their views on farm policy. Mr. Leavell has been playing piano for the Rolling Stones for 24 years. In his other life, he operates a private forestry plantation near Macon, Ga., and by a magic chemistry of his twin professions, has become a top spokesman and lobbyist for the nation's thousands of private forest owners.

He doesn't kid himself. Mr. Leavell knows that journalists and the countless audiences he addresses sit still for the tree lecture partly because he rubs shoulders with Mick and Keith. Or, if they are music fans of a certain antiquity, because of his piano work on a true national heirloom, the Allman Brothers instrumental "Jessica."

He joined the band in 1972, just 20 years old, when the group was putting itself back together after Duane Allman's fatal motorcycle crash. "I was thinking about how I'd establish my instrument in the band," recalls Mr. Leavell. That's when the band's surviving guitarist, Dickey Betts, came through the studio door with a new tune penned while listening to Django Reinhardt records with his baby daughter, Jessica.

But enough of the history of classic rock, volume one. Mr. Leavell wants to talk trees.

Peel away the glamour and higher-risk activities than even most baby boomers managed in their youth, and Mr. Leavell turns out to have much in common with the rest of the tribe.

With hard work and luck, he secured his little piece of heaven. But paradise comes with headaches. At 53, he finds himself worrying about taxes, regulation, foreign competition and how to pass to their children what he and his wife, Rose Lane Leavell, have built.

In 1981, the couple inherited 1,200 rural acres from Rose Lane's grandmother. The first challenge was how to pay the estate taxes. With much gnashing of teeth, they sold a parcel of land that had been in her family for 100 years for a down payment to the IRS, spending the next 15 years paying off the balance.

Challenge two was how to make the land productive without Mr. Leavell having to give up touring to tend crops or cattle. Answer: Plant trees.

As time went on, the couple enlarged the property by purchasing more land. They added nature trails for school kids. They added a hunting lodge, with Mr. Leavell himself, when he's in town, leading paying clients in pursuit of quail. He's written three books, including a new children's book, "The Tree Farmer." But, for the time being, his Rolling Stones income must still help meet the plantation's expenses.

When buttonholing the opinion vanguard, two of Mr. Leavell's hobby horses are taxes and trade. As development drives up land values and property taxes, timber has become increasingly uneconomic. The problem is compounded by a flood of cheap lumber culled from Canada's endless public forests.

Mr. Leavell is steeped in both sides of this long and nasty trade dispute because, before each tour, the Stones spend several weeks rehearsing in Toronto. "They cry NAFTA, NAFTA, NAFTA. We say level playing field." There's only one solution, he says: "I'm not a big fan of subsidies, but when you're facing Canada, which does nothing but subsidize its timber, you gotta play the game."

He offers plenty of good environmental reasons why private forest owners should be coddled as a matter of public policy. Trees scrub carbon dioxide from the air, help purify the water, provide habitat for birds and critters, etc.

Here Mr. Leavell, a man of gentle and courtly demeanor, is engaged in what inevitably must be characterized as special pleading. I explain to him that the Journal editorial page has long been in favor of eliminating farm subsidies, not spreading them to new classes of landowners. And while trees yield public benefits, they also yield Mr. Leavell a great deal of private satisfaction, for which some taxpayers might feel perfectly comfortable letting him pick up the whole tab.

But let's not be too dogmatic. Lobbying is a great and necessary privilege in a free society. As Mr. Leavell has been known to tell audiences, our elected leaders work for us, we don't work for them, and it's entirely proper for citizens to convey their needs and interests to their elected representatives.

Nor does he seem primarily concerned with his own interests. After all, he's got the musical income to subsidize his rural activities. But he does seem to take quite seriously his role as spokesman for thousands of landowners who, beset by sprawl and rising taxes, are forced to sell family forest land to developers that they'd rather keep as woody habitat for wildlife.

White-bearded, trim and dapper, Mr. Leavell has a second job for the Stones as the band's unofficial musical director, coaching the gang through a repertoire that changes each night. A high school dropout from deepest Alabama, was he surprised to discover he had a knack for management? He nods his head: "Especially public speaking. To stand up and give my views in public -- that's something I never would have considered. Now I love it."

Meanwhile, his bemused bandmates have become accepting of the inevitability of a certain amount of tree talk on tour. Put it down to transatlantic cultural exchange: With his missionary enthusiasm and passion for self-improvement, Mr. Leavell exhibits what many would call the best features of the American character.

Cross Country: Union Man

Raleigh, N.C. -- Presidential hopeful John Edwards is fond of telling us that he's the son of a mill worker. And, although he now lives in a mansion and sports expensive haircuts, he also has another thing in common with some wage earners. He's betting his future employment on the power of organized labor.

But is this a safe bet? In Tar Heel, N.C., where organized labor is trying to unionize the largest meat processing plant in the world, that is a pressing question. And it's one that even Paula Deen, a popular host of a down-home cooking show on Food Network, may have to answer.

Smithfield Foods slaughters more than 30,000 hogs a day in Tar Heel, employs some 5,500 people and pays competitive wages -- especially for the rural South. But the United Food and Commercial Workers union wants to organize the plant anyway, arguing that it will protect workers.

So far Smithfield workers aren't going along. They have voted against forming a union, twice, and would likely do so again if another secret ballot election is held.

Undeterred, union supporters have protested at one of Ms. Deen's book signings demanding that she cut ties to Smithfield. The union also wants to dispense with elections and unionize the plant through a controversial process called "card check" -- which merely requires gathering signatures from a majority of workers.

This is where Mr. Edwards enters the fray. He supports the union in its fight against Smithfield and he supports legislation under consideration in Congress that would make it easier to use the card check instead of an election. Mr. Edwards also recently sent a letter to Smithfield CEO Larry Pope demanding that he "protect the right of workers" to bargain collectively. He wants Mr. Pope to support the card check.

This -- his support for dispensing with secret ballot elections in the name of workers' rights -- makes Mr. Edwards one of the most pro- union presidential candidates in a long time. And it is a departure from who he was when he was elected to the Senate in 1998 as a Southern centrist. That reputation led then-Vice President Al Gore to consider tapping him as a running mate in 2000, and it was one reason why John Kerry put him on the ticket in 2004.

Over the past three years, Mr. Edwards has moved sharply to the left. Indeed, he has lashed himself to the mast of organized labor and steered hard to port. His bet is that service-worker unions will propel him to a surprise victory in the early Nevada presidential caucus, giving him a shot at beating the better-financed campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

He also feels that he has found an underserved constituency -- people displaced by the New Economy. And he is on to something. Outside of edge cities and burgeoning metro areas, the painful churning in the economy is easy to spot. Think boarded-up textile mills.

Granted, this isn't the image North Carolina has as a prototypical New South state. The banking capital of Charlotte and the knowledge- worker Mecca of the Research Triangle are more familiar symbols. But North Carolina used to have one of the nation's highest rates of employment and economic production in manufacturing, which offered good pay and stable employment for people with relatively little education.

Over the past decade, however, there was a big change. Manufacturing made up just 22% of North Carolina's gross state product in 2005, down from 30% in 1997. Nationally, manufacturing's share of economic output only fell half as much (from 18% to 14%) during that time. Notwithstanding solid growth in Charlotte and other areas, North Carolina has trailed the nation in most measures of economic performance since the mid-1990s. Many North Carolinians still work in small industrial cities and rural counties, but, for the most part, they've had to be retrained at great effort and haven't yet replaced their former incomes.

Recognizing public trepidation about these events, Mr. Edwards and the labor movement lay blame on the North American Free Trade Agreement, other free-trade pacts and the decline of unionization. But international trade didn't start with NAFTA, nor did the downward trend in manufacturing. Many textile executives in this state even supported NAFTA, hoping to join with lower-cost factories south of the border and thereby compete with Asia producers. The problem is that the Chinese -- and others -- are now making better quality products than they used to. American consumers are getting more for their money.

The union response has been to push for higher wages and to oppose moving or laying off workers. That has made it harder to keep manufacturing jobs. Consider the textile giant Pillowtex, which was once a fixture in Cabarrus County under the name Fieldcrest Cannon. In the late 1990s it was unionized by the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees (UNITE). In 2002, the company emerged from bankruptcy and sought partners to complete a turnaround and keep at least some of its domestic production. One was Springs Industries in South Carolina. But UNITE helped scuttle the Springs deal in April 2003, fearing the loss of its newly won foothold at Pillowtex. A few months later Pillowtex closed its Cabarrus County mill, leaving the union nothing left to stand on.

It turns out that exercising political power through a union isn't a substitute for innovation, retraining and other steps necessary to make economies competitive. Look at the numbers. From 1997 to 2005 the 10 states with the highest rates of union membership -- which include California, New York and Michigan, among others -- had slower growth than the bottom 10 states. North Carolina is among just five states with union membership rates below 5%. But it also has a predilection for raising taxes -- the Tax Foundation estimated this year it that it has the 19th heaviest tax burden in the country, up from 36th in 2000. Further unionizing the workforce will likely only make the state look more like the old Northeast and Rustbelt than the New South.

As Mr. Edwards urges private-sector unionization as the best way to protect middle class jobs, he can only hope that unions are better at fulfilling electoral promises than economic ones.

Bending on Steel

The distance the current Democratic presidential contenders have strayed from the Clinton formula for winning the White House became startlingly clear last week with their reaction to President Bush's decision to remove the tariffs on imported steel that he had imposed 21 months before.

The Democrats had a free shot at Bush for inconsistency, and most of them took it. But every e-mailed comment I saw from them said or implied that they would not have responded as Bush did when the World Trade Organization ruled that the tariffs were unjustified and European nations threatened to slap $2.2 billion of retaliatory levies on U.S. products.

The party whose last president fought against protectionism and for international agreements to liberalize trade has moved a long way in the other direction.

For some of the candidates, this was a no-brainer. Rep. Richard Gephardt of Missouri opposed NAFTA and the normalization of trade relations with China during the time Bill Clinton was president -- a stand that has earned him support from most of the major industrial unions this year. His comment that "the president's action today demonstrates a callous disregard for the workers and the communities whose jobs and livelihoods have been decimated by unfair competition" was entirely predictable.

So was the similar blast from Rep. Dennis Kucinich. His home state of Ohio is a major steel producer, and many thought that Bush's original decision to impose stiff tariffs on foreign steel was a bid to strengthen his reelection hand precisely in such steelmaking states as Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia.

But consider Sen. Joe Lieberman of Connecticut, a consistent supporter of liberal trade policies throughout his career and a backer of the major trade agreements. Rather than reiterate those beliefs, he said: "We need a manufacturing plan with a spine of steel to promote American businesses and workers, not a manufactured plan that bends with every gust of wind."

Former Vermont governor Howard Dean, who has been steadily tacking away from his earlier support of NAFTA and free trade as he tries to head off Gephardt in Iowa, went further than Lieberman. "The president's decision to lift the steel tariffs early is just another example of this administration playing politics with people's lives," Dean said. "When he imposed the tariffs, the president's rhetoric suggested that he actually cared about American steelworkers, their families and the communities in which they live. If that were the case, he would not be lifting them today."

Within days after this bow to protectionism, Dean was endorsed by former vice president Al Gore, the same man who had defended NAFTA and free trade in a notable debate with Ross Perot -- another sign of the seismic shift among Democrats on this issue.

But the most interesting case is retired Gen. Wesley Clark. He is the favorite of many Clintonians, including Mickey Kantor, a key operative in Clinton's 1992 campaign and later his top trade official. Just a few weeks ago, I attended a news conference where Kantor joined two others who had served as special trade representative in Republican administrations, Carla Hills and Clayton Yeutter, in urging the Bush administration to take bolder steps to eliminate trade barriers. Kantor said specifically that while he thought at the time the steel tariffs were imposed that they were justified, it was imperative that they be lifted now -- as Bush subsequently did.

But Clark obviously did not consult Kantor, a senior adviser, on this question. In a most peculiar fashion, Clark first issued a statement that accused Bush of "taking his cues" from "steel industry executives" he had been with "at a fundraiser in Pittsburgh." That made no sense, because the steel executives wanted the tariffs to remain in effect. So, 26 minutes later, came a correction from Clark's Little Rock headquarters, eliminating the bogus charge and complaining that Bush "still has no strategy to help the 2.6 million manufacturing workers who have lost their jobs."

Those job losses are real and have been underway for years. The Bush White House, with its politically driven and inconsistent actions, in effect has confessed that it has no answers to the problem. The Democrats are more than eager to exploit the situation and offer, with varying degrees of conviction and coherence, formulas they claim will help revive the manufacturing sector.

What is being lost in the debate is the conviction that led Clinton -- and his Republican predecessors -- to place the United States on the side of reducing trade barriers and expanding international markets. This issue is a lot more serious than either party's approach to it would ever let you know.
